examples.title: Diffusion
examples.description: This example shows how you can measure the diffusion coefficient using the mean square displacement. The white atoms have mass 1 while the red atoms have mass 4. This results in the red atoms having diffusion coefficient half the value of the white ones.
examples.analysisDescription:
# About this simulation
We simulate two Lennard Jones particle types with masses 1.0 and 4.0. The diffusion coefficient [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_diffusivity](scales like) D$\propto 1/\sqrt{m}$, so we should see a factor 2 higher diffusion coefficient for the small molecules.

examples.title: 2D diffusion coefficient MSD
examples.description: We measure the diffusion coefficient using the mean square displacement.
examples.analysisDescription:
# About this simulation
We measure the diffusion coefficient using the mean square displacement.

examples.title: 2D diffusion coefficient VACF
examples.description: We measure the diffusion coefficient using the velocity auto correlation function.
examples.analysisDescription:
# About this simulation
We measure the diffusion coefficient using the velocity auto correlation function.

examples.title: Protein folding
examples.description: During this short simulation the protein evolves from an unfolded initial conformation to a misfolded conformation. It can take a very long time.

examples.title: 2D Lennard Jones fluid
examples.description: This simulation consists a binary 2D gas of LJ particles.
examples.author: Simon Gravelle

examples.title: 3D Lennard Jones fluid
examples.description: This simulation consists a binary 3D gas of LJ particles.
examples.author: Simon Gravelle

examples.title: Large nanoporous SiO2
examples.description: A nanoporous (porosity 0.75) silica glass with 1.5 million atoms.

examples.title: Generate nanoporous silica
examples.description: Generate a nanoporous silica structure from betacristobalite using the vashishta potential.

examples.title: Hydrocarbon oxcidation
examples.description: Hydrocarbons (such as pentane) will at high temperatures react with oxygen and form water, CO, CO2, HO2 and OH. After around 3000 timesteps, we see some interesting reactions forming new molecules.

examples.title: SiC nanoparticle
examples.description: A silicon carbide (SiC) nano particle in a carbon gas. The whole system is neutral, but initially, the particle has net charge. In this simulation, you can observe how the carbon gas attaches to the surface. The system cools down from 2200 K to 500 K.

examples.title: Faceted SiC nanoparticle
examples.description: A faceted SiC nano particle. All facets are of the same type (110 planes), but due a nucleation barrier during a volume conserving shape change (see Mullins, Rohrer 2000) two of the surfaces are prevented from reaching equilibrium.

examples.title: Single water molecule
examples.description: A single water molecule using the vashishta potential.

examples.title: Water vapor
examples.description: Low density water gas using the vashishta potential.

examples.title: Pattern formation in granular materials
examples.description: When particles (like sand, but really any particle) lie on a vibrating surface, there are various patterns that suddenly appear for certain values for the frequency and amplitude. In this simulation, you will see one such pattern. It might take some time, so be patient.

examples.title: Graphene Oxcide nanoparticle
examples.description: The simulation consists of a single graphene oxide particle with a few water molecules. The initial GO nanoparticle has been generated using [make graphitics].
examples.author: Simon Gravelle

examples.title: Carbon nanotube under deformation
examples.description: The simulation consists of a single carbon nanotube (CNT) in vacuum. At the beginning of the simulation, a few atoms are removed from the CNT. The CNT is divided into three parts: the central part and the two edges. The two edges are forced to move, which leads to the gradual elongation of the CNT. Eventually, the CNT breaks. The breaking of the chemical bonds is permitted by the use of a reactive force field (AIREBO).
examples.author: Simon Gravelle

examples.title: NaCl solution
examples.description: The simulation consists of a bulk solution of NaCl in water.
examples.author: Simon Gravelle

examples.title: Adsorption combined with diffusion create pink noise in nanopore
examples.description: The simulation consists of particles diffusing inside a cylindrical nanopore. The surface of the nanopore is covered with adsorbing sites, and the particles reversibly adsorb at the inner surface of the nanopore. The adsorption/desorption processes are modelled using bond/create and bond/break commands respectively. A bond forms if a particle comes close enough to a trap. An additional harmonic potential is added to trapped particles. The wall of the cylinder is modelled using the wall/region command.
examples.author: Simon Gravelle

examples.title: Silica beta cristobalite
examples.description: Beta cristobalite crystal using the vashishta potential.

examples.title: Zeolite ZSM-5
examples.description: Zeolite ZSM-5 using the vashishta potential.

examples.title: Crack 2D
examples.description: Crack propagation in a 2d solid.

examples.title: Couette flow 2D
examples.description: Couette flow in a 2d channel.

examples.title: Poiseuille flow 2D
examples.description: Poiseuille flow in a 2d channel.

examples.title: Friction 2D
examples.description: Frictional contact of spherical asperities between 2d surfaces.

examples.title: CMAP 5-body
examples.description: CMAP 5-body contributions to CHARMM force field.

examples.title: Deposit atoms
examples.description: Deposition of atoms onto a 3d substrate.

examples.title: Deposit molecules
examples.description: Deposition of molecules onto a 3d substrate.

examples.title: Micelle
examples.description: Self-assembly of small lipid-like molecules into 2d bilayers.

examples.title: 2d obstacle
examples.description: Flow around two voids in a 2d channel.

examples.title: Peptide solvation
examples.description: Dynamics of a small solvated peptide chain (5-mer).

examples.title: 2d pour.
examples.description: Pouring of granular molecules into a 2d box, then chute flow.

examples.title: 2d molecule pour
examples.description: Pouring of granular molecules into a 2d box, then chute flow.

examples.title: 3d pour
examples.description: Pouring of granular particles into a 3d box, then chute flow.

examples.title: Shear
examples.description: sideways shear applied to 2d solid.

examples.title: Shear with void
examples.description: Sideways shear applied to 2d solid with a void.

examples.title: Polymer through hole
examples.description: This example contains a (crude and somewhat simple) example of the translocation of a (rather short) polymer through a hole in a wall, surrounded by an explicit LJ solvent.

examples.title: Alkane chain
examples.description: This example is a simple simulation of a long alkane chain, in a vacuum at room temperature using the OPLSAA force field.

examples.title: Benzene
examples.description: This example shows how to build a box of benzene molecules using the AMBER/GAFF force-field.

examples.title: Metaphase chromatin
examples.description: This is an implementation of the "two-stage" model used by Maxim Imakaev in the Naumova et Al 2013 Science paper on metaphase chromatin.

examples.title: Ethylene and benzene
examples.description: This example shows how to simulate a mixture of ethylene and benzene using the AMBER/GAFF force field.

examples.title: Ice crystal
examples.description: A simulation of an ice crystal using SPCE water and the shake algorithm.

examples.title: Methane
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to build a simulation containing a box of methane.

examples.title: Water in nanotube
examples.description: This is a small version of a carbon-nanotube, water capillary system.

examples.title: Methane in water
examples.description: This example contains a mixture of SPCE water and methane. The methane molecules use OPLSAA force-field.

examples.title: Salt water
examples.description: This example contains a mixture of SPCE water and salt (NaCl).

examples.title: TIP3P water and isobutane
examples.description: The simulation consists of a mixture of isobutane and water. Over time (less than 1 ns), the two molecules phase-separate.

examples.title: Ammonia-Borine (AB)
examples.description: Combustion of Ammonia-Borine (AB) can be simulated with ReaxFF. Two AB molecules meet and a H<sub>2</sub> molecule is formed.

examples.title: Iron(III) hydroxide
examples.description: In this simulation, we see low density Iron(III) hydroxide (Fe(OH)3) at high temperature.

examples.title: RDX explosive
examples.description: RDX is an organic compound normally used as an explosive, especially in world war II.

examples.title: Zeolite SSZ-13
examples.description: This structure is a zeolite called SSZ-13 (or CHA) and has one of the silicon sites replaced with Aluminum and a hydrogen atom.

examples.title: Vanadium Oxide
examples.description: In this simulation, we see vanadium oxide being simulated using ReaxFF at high temperature.

examples.title: Zn(OH)2
examples.description: In this simulation, we see Zn(OH)2 at high temperature.
